THE CONTINUING CRYPTO WARS: A CALL FOR RE-THINKING END-TO-END ENCRYPTION

In the ongoing battle of the crypto wars, Graeme Biggar, the director general of the U.K.'s National Crime Agency (NCA), has urged Meta (formerly Facebook) to reconsider its implementation of end-to-end encryption (E2EE) on Instagram. This call follows a joint declaration by European police chiefs, including the U.K.'s, expressing concern over the expanding use of E2EE by the tech industry, and the potential threats it poses to child safety and the investigation of illegal activities.

The NCA's Concerns and the Role of Law Enforcement

Graeme Biggar, in an interview with BBC Radio 4's Today program, emphasized the necessity for law enforcement agencies to have access to information that could help protect the public from organized crime and serious threats. With the increasing use of E2EE, platforms like Meta would not be able to provide law enforcement with the information required to safeguard the public.

Currently, platforms are sending tens of millions of child safety-related reports annually to police forces around the world, which result in the safeguarding of approximately 1,200 children per month and the arrest of around 800 people. The concern is that the rollout of E2EE on Instagram and other platforms could lead to a significant decrease in these reports and compromise efforts to combat child exploitation.

Balancing Privacy and Public Safety

While the NCA supports strong encryption to protect users from cybercrime, Biggar insists that there must be a way for tech companies to provide law enforcement with the necessary information to ensure public safety. This is in line with the joint declaration by European police chiefs, who call for the industry to adopt unspecified technical solutions that can offer robust security and privacy while maintaining the ability to spot illegal activity and report decrypted content to law enforcement.

The European Council adopted a similar "lawful access" mandate for encrypted messaging in December 2020, but the declaration does not specify which technologies should be implemented for scanning problematic content and sending decrypted content to law enforcement. Title: A Bold Blend of Artistry and Artificial Intelligence: The Birth of "AI-conic" Coffee

In a fascinating intersection of tradition and technology, Kaffa Roastery, an esteemed artisan roastery in Helsinki, Finland, has unveiled a new coffee blend crafted with the aid of artificial intelligence (AI). This groundbreaking creation, christened "AI-conic," is a testament to the harmonious blend of human expertise and AI's data-driven insights.

Finland, a nation of 5.6 million people and the world's leading consumer of coffee at 12 kilograms per capita annually, provides the perfect backdrop for this innovative trial. The AI-conic blend, a meticulously curated mixture of four types of beans led by the velvety Fazenda Pinhal from Brazil, is the brainchild of Kaffa and local AI consultancy, Elev.

The partnership aimed to explore how AI could alleviate the workload in a sector that has long been rooted in manual labor and cherishes its artisanal traditions. Elev's AI, comparable to models like ChatGPT and Copilot, was tasked with creating a blend that would appeal to coffee connoisseurs, challenging the boundaries of conventional flavor profiles.

Svante Hampf, Kaffa's managing director and founder, shared that the trial was initiated to explore the potential of AI in coffee roasting. He explained, "We gave descriptions of all our coffee types and their flavors to AI and instructed it to create a new exciting blend." To the surprise of Hampf, the AI selected an unusual combination of four different coffee beans, a departure from the typical two or three bean blends that allow for distinct flavor differentiation.

After the initial test roasting and blind testing, Kaffa's coffee experts concurred that the AI-assisted blend was flawless, requiring no human adjustments. The AI also designed the coffee package label and penned a detailed taste description, defining AI-conic as "a well-balanced blend of sweetness and ripe fruit."

Antti Merilehto, Elev's spokesman, lauded the trial as an exemplification of AI's potential to introduce novel perspectives to seasoned professionals and offer coffee lovers unique taste experiences

Title: Revolutionizing ADHD Care for Young Kids: Clarity Pediatrics

Introduction

Raising children with ADHD (Attention Deficit Hyperactivity Disorder) can be a daunting task for parents. With long waiting periods for diagnosis and high treatment costs, many families struggle to access the necessary care. However, Clarity Pediatrics, a chronic care startup, is changing the game by reducing wait times and offering affordable ADHD therapy.

The Problem: Long Waiting Periods and High Costs

Parents seeking professional help for their children with ADHD often face long waiting periods due to a nationwide shortage of psychologists. The process of receiving a diagnosis and beginning therapy can take several months, which can be incredibly frustrating for families. Moreover, the high cost of treatment can add up to thousands of dollars a year for out-of-network care, making it inaccessible for many families.

Clarity Pediatrics' Solution: Group Therapy for Parents

Clarity Pediatrics offers a solution to this problem by providing behavioral parent training (BPT) in the form of eight-week group therapy sessions for parents of newly diagnosed or previously diagnosed children with ADHD. The American Academy of Pediatrics recommends BPT for families of children with mild-to-moderate ADHD. Since young kids are not mature enough to change their behavior on their own, BPT teaches parents strategies and skills to help their children focus in school and control emotional outbursts.

Clarity's Unique Approach

Clarity's approach is unique because it focuses solely on treating ADHD in kids ages five to 12 by providing diagnosis, therapy, and prescriptions. The company's co-founder, Dr. Alesandro Larrazabal, is a pediatrician trained at UCSF and Stanford, and was in charge of specialty services at Kaiser Permanente. Clarity has already provided online care to thousands of families in California and plans to expand its services to other states in 2024.

TikTok, the popular video-sharing platform, is once again under scrutiny from the European Union (EU). The EU has opened a second formal investigation, suspecting TikTok of violating the Digital Services Act (DSA), an online governance and content moderation framework. The Commission is considering imposing interim measures that could force TikTok to suspend access to the TikTok Lite app in the EU, due to concerns about potential mental health risks for users. However, TikTok has been given until April 24 to argue against the measure, allowing the app to remain accessible for now.

The DSA, implemented to ensure a safe online environment, imposes penalties of up to 6% of global annual turnover for confirmed violations. If EU enforcers decide that TikTok has broken the law, ByteDance (TikTok's parent company) could face hefty fines. This investigation is the second probe launched by the EU against TikTok, following an ongoing investigation into multiple aspects of its DSA compliance since February.

The EU's first TikTok probe, which includes examining the protection of minors, advertising transparency, data access for researchers, and risk management of addictive design and harmful content, will not focus on the TikTok Lite app. The latest investigation will specifically target TikTok Lite, a version of the video-sharing platform that launched earlier this month in France and Spain. This version includes a "task and reward" feature, where users can earn points for watching or liking videos, which can be exchanged for rewards such as Amazon gift vouchers or TikTok's digital currency.

The EU is concerned about the potential negative impact of this feature on the mental health of young users, as it may stimulate addictive behavior. The Commission has requested ByteDance to produce a risk assessment of the feature, but the company has not complied. As a result, the EU suspects a "prima facie infringement of the DSA" by ByteDance.

Pomelo: The Remittance Startup Revolutionizing International Money Transfers Through Credit

Pomelo, a groundbreaking startup that amalgamates international money transfers with credit, has recently secured $35 million in a Series A funding round led by Dubai-based venture firm Vy Capital. This announcement comes alongside the news of a $75 million expansion of their warehouse facility. The round also saw participation from Founders Fund, A Capital, Afore Capital, and other investors. This investment brings Pomelo's total equity capital to $55 million and their warehouse facility funding to $125 million.

Pomelo: A Fresh Approach to Remittance Transfers

Founded by Eric Velasquez Frenkiel, Pomelo first launched in the Philippines in 2022, enabling users in the United States to send money to the country while simultaneously building their credit profile. The startup has created a remittance product on credit card rails by partnering with Mastercard to introduce a new product category called "Send Now, Pay Later" (SNPL). This innovative solution promises faster transactions and no transfer fees compared to traditional cross-border money movement.

How Pomelo Works

Pomelo functions by providing users with an account that includes credit cards. The account creator can set limits, pause cards, and monitor spending habits. Senders can transfer funds, in the form of credit, to family members, which Pomelo claims offers instant access to funds, fraud and chargeback protection, and for potential immigrants who might use this service to send money back home, a chance to enhance their credit score with more transaction history. The company generates revenue primarily through interchange revenue, with foreign exchange being a smaller component.

title: Linux Kernel: Stability, Security & LTS Releases Explained
post_content:
Title: The State of the Linux Kernel: A Comprehensive Overview

Introduction

The Linux kernel, the heart of the Linux operating system, is constantly evolving, with new versions and updates being released regularly. To stay updated on the latest developments in the Linux kernel, subscribing to the Linux Kernel Mailing List or Linux Weekly News (LWN) is recommended. However, for a broad and quick overview, attending a state-of-the-kernel presentation by a Linux kernel developer, such as Jonathan Corbet, can be extremely informative.

The Calm and Steady Linux Kernel

At Open Source Summit North America in Seattle, Corbet discussed the state of the Linux kernel, stating that everything is "calm and steady and boring" with the next kernel, Linux 6.9. This calmness is good news, as it indicates that the kernel is stable and functioning as intended.

However, Corbet also highlighted some concerning news. Due to the unique nature of the Linux kernel, bugs have the potential to become vulnerabilities, making the kernel a prime target for attacks. To address this issue, Linux kernel developers have started issuing their own Common Vulnerabilities and Exposures (CVE) notifications, with hundreds of CVEs assigned in recent months.

Ensuring the Safety and Security of Linux Systems

To ensure the safety and security of Linux systems, running long-term stable (LTS) kernel releases is recommended. LTS releases have fixed CVEs, and as new issues are patched, they're ported into the LTS kernels. However, it should be noted that LTS releases are now only supported for two years, not six, as was the case in the past.

If you're not sure what version of the kernel you're running, simply run the following command from the shell:

$ uname -r

If you get any result besides a blank, you're running an LTS.

The Decrease in Use of Older Kernel Versions

The reason for the decrease in support for older kernel versions is the decline in use and the practical difficulties of maintaining outdated software. This change underscores a broader shift toward current versions, which are easier to support and secure.

The Nostalgic App Experience

Nostalgic apps like Mood.camera, Lapse, Dispo, and Later Cam offer users a chance to capture photos using vintage filters and settings. These apps often lack modern features like live previews, editing tools, or the option to import photos, encouraging users to focus on the moment and appreciate the simplicity of the past.

Mood.camera, for instance, takes users back to the days of physical film rolls by allowing them to switch between retro filters and adjust quality and tone with a dial. The app does not have a live preview, a feature that encourages users to concentrate on their subject and the environment.

A Deliberate Approach

The creators of nostalgic camera apps aim to recapture the magic lost in photography's shift towards convenience and control. By imposing limitations, these apps nudge users to be more present and less concerned with perfecting their images.

For example, Mood.camera's developer, Alex Fox, started working on the app in October 2023 and released a beta version on Reddit. A community of photographers helped refine the app by taking over 100,000 photos, contributing to its development and success.

Sustainable Revenue Models

While some nostalgic app creators initially attracted investors, they eventually adopted sustainable revenue models to maintain their independence. Apps like Mood.camera offer a free trial period, after which users can choose a $1.99 monthly subscription or a one-time fee of $14.99.

This approach allows indie developers to create unique and innovative apps while building a loyal user base. By embracing the nostalgic touch, these developers tap into a growing market of users who seek a more authentic and engaging photography experience.
